title: 106_hr3207
content: The Act may be cited as the "Superfund Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1999". The Congress acknowledges the success of the Superfund Innovative Treatment and Evaluation (SITE) program in promoting innovative clean-up technologies, resulting in cost savings and faster remediation at contaminated sites. The Environmental Protection Agency's Science Advisory Board has praised the program's accomplishments as impressive. The University Hazardous Substance Research Centers have been crucial in researching and developing clean-up technologies for environmental contamination. The SITE program should be reauthorized to address emerging challenges in remediation and transfer technology to more sites. The University Hazardous Substance Research Centers have played a key role in developing clean-up technologies for environmental contamination. The SITE program should be reauthorized to address new challenges in remediation and expand technology transfer to various sites. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS. Section 111(n) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to update the fiscal years for fund usage and training purposes. The amounts available in the Fund for section 311(a) are limited to $35,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004, with a maximum of 10% for training. Section 311(a) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended by removing paragraph (6). Section 311(b) is also amended to allow the Administrator to enter agreements for hazardous substances projects at appropriate sites. The amendment to Section 311 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 includes changes such as removing paragraph (6) and allowing the Administrator to enter agreements for hazardous substances projects at suitable sites. Additionally, there is a provision for technology transfer agreements with federal agencies for remediation and containment of hazardous substances. The amendment to Section 311 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 involves changes in responsibilities of hazardous substance research centers, including research, training, technical assistance, and technology transfer to local, State, and regional entities. The amendment to Section 311 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 involves changes in responsibilities of hazardous substance research centers, including research, training, technical assistance, and technology transfer to local, State, and regional entities. This includes funding maintenance for each center at a level not less than that funded in fiscal year 1999. The amendment to Section 311 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 changes the responsibilities of hazardous substance research centers, including research, training, technical assistance, and technology transfer. Funding maintenance for each center is required at a level not less than that funded in fiscal year 1999 until the next competitive selection process is completed by the Administrator.
